2.text:
Preamble
I am absolutely delighted tonight to welcome

4.text:
you all here for what is, for us, quite an
unusual experiment. The reason I say that

13.text:
is that I do not know of any previous Annual
General Meeting of the NHS at any time in

23.text:
its 65-year history. Nor do I know, actually,
of any comparable event on the part of any

32.text:
other major national public-sector organisation.
So for us, this symbolises the new approach

40.text:
that we are trying to take in our responsibilities
with regard to the NHS.

47.text:
Aims
So the meeting tonight has two principal functions.

52.text:
The first is the formality -- this is formally
our AGM. However, the formality extends to

60.text:
the past. The formality extends to that period
in our setup when we were the NHS Commissioning

68.text:
Board Authority, and it extends to that period
that ran from October last year through until

74.text:
March this year, to the end of the financial
year.

78.text:
That is the formal bit, and we will try to
make that as pleasant as possible. However,

84.text:
for me that is not the dominant part of this
evening. The dominant part of this evening

88.text:
is that this is a real meeting in which we
have the engagement with those to whom we

94.text:
owe responsibility and accountability, and
that is the patients and the people of England.

99.text:
Agenda
Tonight I am joined by the board directors,

104.text:
who I will invite onto the stage in a few
minutes' time. However, before I do so, the

110.text:
order of service is along the following lines.
I will say a few more words about NHS England,

116.text:
what we are, what we believe in and what we
are doing. I will be followed by our Chief

122.text:
Executive, Sir David Nicholson, who will talk
about where we are going and what the future

127.text:
holds for us. He will be followed by our Finance
Director, Paul Baumann, who will talk about

132.text:
the accounts for those six months in an exciting
and uplifting and illuminating way -- I am

141.text:
sorry Paul, I could not help that! However,
that is the nature of the formal business

148.text:
of the evening.
At that stage, I propose to invite up here

153.text:
Olivia Butterworth. Just to give background
for those of you who were not part of the

157.text:
workshops this afternoon, we ran five absolutely
fascinating workshops. We brought in patients

165.text:
and members of the public to help us to understand
how it felt to be at the other end of what

171.text:
NHS England does. What is it that we can do
better in order to carry forward the ambitions

178.text:
that we have for the NHS in England, during
a period which is going to be perhaps the

184.text:
most challenging period the NHS has ever faced
-- a period in which we will encounter the

190.text:
parallel forces of increased demand, with
in particular the phenomenon of an ageing

198.text:
population living with multiple long-term
conditions, on the one hand, and a stagnant

204.text:
economy on the other? How do we square the
circle? How do we make the NHS a living social

212.text:
institution, as it was born to be, providing
support from cradle to grave, not just for

218.text:
ill-health but for the prevention of ill-health,
in an environment where everything becomes

223.text:
much more difficult?
So after we have had Olivia's presentation

230.text:
of the feedback from those five groups -- and
I have heard some of that already this afternoon,

235.text:
and I can tell you it is absolutely superb
and really quite moving -- we will go into

241.text:
the final part of the annual general meeting,
in which there will be a Q&A session which

247.text:
I will moderate. At that stage, I will invite
all the remaining members of the board of

254.text:
NHS England to join me here on the platform.
NHS England

257.text:
Review of performance
So, let me offer a few words on where we have

260.text:
been and where we are going. NHS England was
part of the government's reforms in 2012.

269.text:
The purpose of setting us up, and of having
an independent chairman and independent directors

274.text:
on the board, was to try to distance the NHS's
day-to-day operational management from the

281.text:
political framework within which it has always
operated. That is not a straightforward exercise,

287.text:
because of course there is enormous political
interest in the NHS, and it has great political

292.text:
salience. The NHS in England consumes over
8% of the GDP of England. It is taxpayers'

300.text:
money for which we have responsibility, and
that is a huge responsibility -- to try to

304.text:
ensure that every pound that is invested in
the NHS secures best value for taxpayers and

311.text:
for patients and the public. This is, after
all, an indivisible whole.

316.text:
What we had envisaged as the legislation was
being enacted was that we would function as

323.text:
an arms-length body with the Secretary of
State for Health, and that the relationship

328.text:
would largely be mediated by something called
a mandate. The mandate is a set of outcomes

334.text:
that the government wishes us to secure, set
at a fairly high level in terms of abstractions

339.text:
but ones that you could understand -- domains
such as reducing premature mortality. How

345.text:
can we improve the quality of care in the
NHS so that few people die early and that

351.text:
we enhance the quality of life for us survivors
through to our death, which is the inevitable

357.text:
end of the road? But how do we make the NHS
responsive to a new environment in which we

364.text:
have an increasingly large proportion of elderly
people?

368.text:
The early months, which the formal part of
this meeting will be reviewing, were in effect

375.text:
a setup time. We were being set up. That involved
us acquiring premises, acquiring staff, working

382.text:
out our policies, trying to understand how
it would be from the 1st April this year that

388.text:
we would assume operational command through
commissioning healthcare for the population

394.text:
of England. As we went through that period,
we could explore the sheer complexity of what

403.text:
has happened. In 2010, there were some 50,000
people employed within the NHS in commissioning.

412.text:
By 2013, on the 1st of April, when we took
on our full powers, that number had fallen

419.text:
by 17,500. There has been a significant reduction,
which on the one hand causes a significant

425.text:
financial benefit, but on the other hand means
a loss of corporate memory.

431.text:
On the 1st April our payroll went up from
around 120 full-time staff to around 6,200

439.text:
full-time staff overnight. They came to us
from 161 different organisations. The sheer

445.text:
complexity of drawing together this new organisation
from that background has been almost overwhelming,

452.text:
and above all tonight, I want in public to
pay tribute to the staff who made that happen.

459.text:
They have had to work through the last few
months under the appallingly challenging conditions

466.text:
of working in a new organisation, in premises
that are still being organised and fitted-out

473.text:
with IT systems and with payrolls. The staff
have made this happen and have made the transition

480.text:
as smooth as it has. It has not been a scandal;
it has not been an NHS project that fell flat

488.text:
on its face. It has been an NHS project that
has been successful for its almost invisible

494.text:
performance, and for that, I owe my colleagues
across the whole of the organisation a huge

503.text:
Let me then move to the future. We have, as
I outlined earlier, an enormous set of challenges.

510.text:
It is not just to square the circle, as I
mentioned before, but to understand how in

516.text:
every aspect of our business we can do it
better -- how we make better use of data;

522.text:
how we try to spread a culture across the
provider sector which focuses on seven-day

528.text:
services, a culture which looks very carefully
at the handover point between different providers

536.text:
when patients are at their most vulnerable.
How do we address those scandalous stories

542.text:
that came out of the Francis report -- of
a real failure of a culture of care and compassion

550.text:
with regard to some of our most vulnerable
citizens? The priorities that we choose and

556.text:
the way in which we go about this can only
be helped and moulded by our understanding

562.text:
of the wishes and the needs and the priorities
of patients and people. We are committed to

567.text:
that. Our strapline is, 'The NHS belongs to
the people'. Our strapline is, 'We want to

574.text:
provide high-quality care for now and for
all future generations'.

578.text:
Retirement of Sir David Nicholson
Ladies and gentlemen, that is by way of introduction.

583.text:
I now wish to call upon Sir David Nicholson,
but before I do so, let me say a few words

590.text:
about where we stand with relation to the
Chief Executiveship of the NHS. David Nicholson

596.text:
has given outstanding service, not only as
Chief Executive of the old model of the NHS

602.text:
but also of the new model that we have run
from 1st April. He has been the linchpin that

608.text:
has allowed us to move through the most complex
period of transition from the old into the

613.text:
new. Shortly after that process was completed,
he indicated that he wished to retire, with

620.text:
effect from the 1st of April this year. We
are currently in the process of leading a

624.text:
global search for his successor. We talk sometimes
in these circumstances about big shoes, which

630.text:
is not a literal reflection on the size of
David's feet but is a figurative expression

636.text:
of the size of the role, the enormous responsibility
of this role. And you have my full assurance

643.text:
that the non-executive directors, whose appointment
this is, in conjunction with the Health Secretary,

650.text:
are conducting the search with all appropriate
vigour and rigour on a global basis.

656.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, please will you welcome
Sir David Nicholson.

662.text:
Okay, well, good evening everybody. For the
Annual General Meeting, I was going to talk

671.text:
about the bit of our history during those
six months as a commissioning board. I am

679.text:
not sure whether I should do a retirement
speech after!

682.text:
Anyway, it is great to be here at the Annual
General Meeting of NHS England. It is extraordinary

688.text:
when I think about how it is probably three
years ago when we sat in a room with the Secretary

696.text:
of State at the time, Andrew Lansley, and
talked about his vision for the NHS, and they

702.text:
were kind of words on a page. After this period,
to have this organisation up and running,

709.text:
is extraordinary. And I absolutely agree with
Malcolm: this idea of having a national body

714.text:
for the NHS, for the very first time in this
way, that can report to the public about how

719.text:
the NHS, in overall terms, is improving outcomes
for patients, is a really, I think, significant

725.text:
and important step for the NHS. Indeed, I
think we should be able to say in years to

732.text:
come when we look back that this was, I think,
a significant turning point for the NHS going

737.text:
forward.
Building potential for the future

741.text:
However, the work we did over those six months
was all about building -- building potential

748.text:
for the future. As we set up the NHS Commissioning
Board Authority we worked really hard to build

755.text:
the organisation, but more importantly than
that, to build the kind of organisation that

760.text:
we all wanted to belong to -- one which was
completely consistent with the values and

766.text:
principles of the NHS, of our patients, of
the public, and of our staff. That is what

772.text:
we attempted to do. That work showed itself
in terms of the way we allocated resources

779.text:
across the NHS and in the way we produced
a really important document for us, a really

785.text:
important document in the sense that it was
setting out our vision for the future and

790.text:
the things that we need to do -- it was called
'Everyone Counts', and it was called 'Everyone

795.text:
Counts' on purpose, because that is what the
NHS is all about: being inclusive for all

800.text:
of our people, no matter where they are, no
matter who they are, no matter where they

804.text:
live. We worked really hard at that.
Lessons learned

809.text:
In doing this, even after 30-odd years at
the NHS, I have learned a whole series of

815.text:
lessons. I think the organisation has learned
during that period. Hopefully we want to build

820.text:
an organisation that, as it goes forward,
learns more and more, both about the job it

825.text:
needs to do but also about the public and
patients that it serves. I would identify

831.text:
three lessons that I think we have learned
through that period, which I think are really

836.text:
important signals for the future as we go
forward.

840.text:
Investing in the future
The first one is to invest in and think about

843.text:
the future. Those of you who have been involved
in the NHS for a long time know how difficult

850.text:
it has been to plan beyond the end of the
financial year -- how difficult it is to think

856.text:
three, five or ten years out about what a
compelling vision for the NHS might be, a

862.text:
vision that we can really work to over that
period. That is why we have announced the

868.text:
call to action; that is why we are absolutely
determined, as an organisation, not to think

875.text:
about how we are going to survive over the
next year to 18 months, but about how we can

879.text:
build a fantastic, sustainable NHS going forward.
That call to action is a critical part of

887.text:
what uniquely NHS England can do. Part of
the workshops today was to think about what

894.text:
that great, compelling vision might be -- not
something that we would create, not something

898.text:
that our Board can sit in a room and think
about what it is, but actually to work with

903.text:
a public, with patients, with clinicians,
with the staff of the NHS, to work out what

909.text:
it might look like in very challenging and
constrained times.

913.text:
Driving transparency
The second lesson that we've learned is not

919.text:
only the importance of transparency but how
we have to drive it even faster and even harder

928.text:
in the future. One of the issues about the
NHS is that there's always been, in my experience,

935.text:
a big difference between what those of us
who are responsible for the service and work

941.text:
in it know about it, and what the public and
what patients know about it. It is obvious

949.text:
in all sorts of ways -- everything from the
way in which sometimes healthcare systems

954.text:
harm patients, right the way through to the
way in which mortality is counted and happens

961.text:
in hospitals. Over the past period, we have
consistently published more and more data,

969.text:
from the outcome data for the 10 specialities
right the way through to a whole plethora

978.text:
of information about mortality in patients
that we have produced.

982.text:
That is very, very uncomfortable for the NHS,
very difficult for the NHS. And every day

987.text:
you can see more data coming out, where we
are being much more transparent about what

992.text:
a real healthcare system is and what the strengths
and weaknesses of it are. It is really difficult,

999.text:
both for people who work in the NHS and who
support the NHS, to see some of this and some

1004.text:
of the criticisms that are laid onto the NHS
as we go forward. However, it is really important

1011.text:
that we do it -- and not only important that
we do it, but that we do more of it and that

1016.text:
we do it faster. Only in that way will we,
in the medium to long term, build confidence

1024.text:
between the service and the patients and public
who use it.

1029.text:
It is going to be very tough, and some people
might say: why would you inflict this pain

1035.text:
on yourself in that way? However, it is absolutely
vital that we do it. In my view, it is the

1041.text:
difference between success and failure of
our healthcare system, the NHS, going forward.

1046.text:
So it is really important that we really drive
faster and harder in terms of transparency.

1051.text:
Thinking about our assets
The third lesson we have learned is to think

1055.text:
about our assets. I am sure that many of us
in the NHS, sometimes when we sit down and

1063.text:
talk about it we say: the problem is x or
the problem is y. That is fine, because we

1071.text:
have to deal with those issues. However, as
an organisation, we really need to think much

1076.text:
more about our assets. Three I would particularly
identify for us.

1082.text:
Clinical Commissioning Groups
The first one is the clinical commissioning

1084.text:
groups. We have created the clinical commissioning
groups. General practitioners and all the

1089.text:
clinicians have created 211 organisations
across the NHS -- brand new organisations

1097.text:
with new ideas, with new potential. I travel
all over the country meeting people in clinical

1103.text:
commissioning groups and it is absolutely
remarkable, the way in which they are bringing

1107.text:
their clinical knowledge, their clinical understanding
to move and change services in a way I could

1113.text:
never have imagined in the past. A critical
part of our role in the future is to nurture

1120.text:
that asset, to give it the support that it
needs, and to make sure that those clinical

1124.text:
commissioning groups can be absolutely fantastic
for their local populations.

1129.text:
Nurturing our staff
The second asset to nurture is our staff,

1134.text:
and I would identify one particular aspect
here. Clearly there is the staff of the NHS

1138.text:
as a whole, but we have a particular responsibility,
I think, for the people who work with us in

1143.text:
NHS England -- just over 6,000 people who
are all over the country, who work in every

1148.text:
locality, in every area. If you think about
what happened in the past and now, the functions

1156.text:
we have taken over as NHS England -- we now
have half the number of staff that we would

1162.text:
have had in the past to do them. So we are
expecting an enormous amount from those people.

1168.text:
It is really important that they get support
and help, and they can be a fantastic asset

1173.text:
for the healthcare system as we go forward,
whether they are directly commissioning services,

1178.text:
whether they are dealing with complaints at
the end of a telephone or directly face-to-face

1182.text:
with patients, or whether they are thinking
about really difficult, knotty decisions,

1189.text:
about the availability of particular drugs
or treatments for those patients. All of those

1195.text:
staff we really do need to support, and I
think they have started to do a remarkable

1199.text:
job for the service.
Patients and the public

1201.text:
The third and final asset that I would identify,
and in a sense the most obvious one, is our

1206.text:
patients and the public. Very often the conversation
starts: 'and the problem about the patients

1216.text:
is' or 'the problem we have to solve in relation
to the public is'. However, we have to see

1222.text:
patients and the public as an asset. If you
think about the scale and nature of the change

1227.text:
we are going to have to see in the NHS as
we struggle to live within the resources that

1230.text:
are made available, the public and patients
have to be part of that solution, whether

1239.text:
it is supporting them in looking after our
own health, whether it is giving people the

1246.text:
tools, the technology to enable them to control
their own health and healthcare, or whether

1252.text:
it is them playing more direct roles in moving
and changing the kinds of services that we

1257.text:
have. That is a fabulous asset for the NHS.
There is great goodwill towards the NHS in

1263.text:
this country from the public and the patients,
and I think we can really make that happen.

1268.text:
Turning points
I talked right at the beginning about this

1272.text:
being, in my view, when we look back, a turning
point. Turning points are really important

1278.text:
for us. They are important for organisations.
Very often you do not notice the turning point

1284.text:
at the time but they are really important.
They are very, very important for us as individuals.

1290.text:
I was at a mental health unit last week called
Mersey Care. They have a fantastic set up

1296.text:
there and they are doing great work with their
patients, providing mental health services

1301.text:
to a large population.
I spent a lot of time with a group of service

1306.text:
users who were talking to me about their turning
point. There were critical things, simple

1312.text:
things. For example, a gentleman said to me
that the turning point for him was when a

1317.text:
charge nurse put their arm around him and
said, 'I and all the staff in this ward are

1324.text:
there to help you get better. We are there
to make you better'. He was astounded when

1332.text:
he heard this, because he assumed they were
there to control him. That turning point,

1337.text:
for him, completely changed his life and his
life chances. Another man said that he had

1344.text:
been in his second detoxification program
when he saw a poster on a wall that said 'Do

1349.text:
you want to be part of a patient and client
user council?' He rang the number, and 10

1357.text:
years later he has had a fantastic change
in his life chances and role in relation to

1363.text:
services.
In 10 years' time when I am long retired from

1371.text:
this organisation I want to be able to look
back and say that this period was the time,

1376.text:
the turning point, when the NHS understood
what transparency was all about; was clear

1382.text:
and open with its staff and its patients;
could make sure that it focused really hard

1388.text:
on the future of the NHS going forward; and
made the really ambitious and courageous decision

1395.text:
to absolutely reinforce high-quality care
for all, now and for future generations. Thank

1403.text:
Paul Baumann
Chief Financial Officer, NHS England

1408.text:
Preamble
Well, good evening. Follow that, as they say.

1412.text:
There are many fascinating topics about finance
that I can come on and talk to you about this

1416.text:
evening. Unfortunately I am not allowed to
talk about any of them. The only thing I am

1419.text:
allowed to talk about is the last year's accounts,
which I am going to struggle to make sexy

1423.text:
in any way at all. So I will at least try
and make my comments brief.

1429.text:
As you have heard from Malcolm and from David,
last year was a transitional year. It was

1432.text:
transitional in two respects, one of which
was that this was clearly a year of setup,

1436.text:
not of real operations. So the numbers that
I will share with you in a minute are reflective

1441.text:
of that fact.
The second thing is, I have a double task

1444.text:
tonight, because we have two sets of accounts.
The first half of the year was in the guise

1448.text:
of the Commissioning Board Authority, the
vehicle that was set up for us to do our first

1453.text:
stage of setup with; and then halfway through
last year we set up as the Commissioning Board,

1458.text:
now known as NHS England. So the accountants
had a double joy of trying to get two sets

1463.text:
of accounts completed in rapid time, and indeed
to then get them approved by the auditors.

1469.text:
I am pleased to say that we got a positive
audit opinion from the National Audit Office.

1474.text:
I am pleased to say that they have now been
laid before parliament, and for those of you

1477.text:
who are looking for something interesting
to read just before you go to bed tonight,

1481.text:
both sets of accounts are available on the
NHS England website in the Publications section,

1487.text:
and indeed at all good booksellers no doubt
-- probably the remainder department, but

1495.text:
So that is the formality of it. Now, despite
the fact that we had a split year, we had

1498.text:
a single budget, which is fine, but that is
really what I am going to comment on for this

1504.text:
brief section. The budget we were given for
the year for the setup was £82 million. This

1510.text:
was set quite early on in the process before
we really knew quite what we were going to

1513.text:
have to do over that period of time. In the
event, we spent just under £62 million, or

1519.text:
roughly three-quarters of the budget that
we had originally been spent.

1523.text:
Staff costs
Most of that reduction was in staff costs,

1526.text:
which reflects the fact that it took us quite
a while to get the recruitment process through

1530.text:
and get the teams recruited; and then, having
recruited them, it took quite a while to get

1533.text:
them released from their current tasks. So
looking at it positively, we managed to achieve

1539.text:
all the things that David and Malcolm have
said with just over half the resource that

1543.text:
was originally envisaged. However, it is really
fair to say, I think, that this resulted in

1548.text:
extremely heavy demands on the very dedicated
team, averaging about 250 people across the

1553.text:
year, who took on those Herculean tasks and
did so with great aplomb during the course

1559.text:
of the year. Many of them were doing that
alongside their roles in the previous world,

1564.text:
as it were: closing down the old and setting
up the new. So I think that is a great tribute

1568.text:
to the people who were part of the setup.
Non-staff costs

1572.text:
Turning to the non-staff costs, they were
slightly lower than we had anticipated -- £42

1575.text:
million compared to £48 million -- a saving
that was achieved despite the fact that in

1581.text:
quite a number of areas we had to bring in
support of one sort or another to plug the

1585.text:
gaps, and Finance was a good example of that
during the course of the year. It is worth

1589.text:
pointing out that all of these costs, clearly,
are mostly focused on setting up the system

1594.text:
as a whole rather than on setting up NHS England
as a single organisation. And the two big

1599.text:
examples I would give you of things which
I think, in their own way, are ground-breaking

1602.text:
and which make up more than half of the costs
that I have just described, are the authorisation

1606.text:
process for CCGs, which we ran during the
course of last year, and secondly (a first

1611.text:
for the NHS) a single financial accounting
and reporting system that covers all 212 organisations

1618.text:
in the commissioning world, which I think
we will look back on and think of as a big

1621.text:
asset as we go forward.
Looking to the future

1624.text:
That is about all I wanted to say about 2012/13.
In terms of budgets, accounting processes

1629.text:
and financial management, it was merely the
appetiser for the excitement to come as we

1634.text:
move from effectively an £80 million setup
budget to an organisation that is now responsible

1639.text:
for looking after £95.6 billion of taxpayers
money, entrusted to us, of course, to get

1645.text:
the best possible outcomes for our patients.
We have set up a good, well-tested planning
